ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a huge appreciation into the amount of work that has gone into trying to figure out how the brain allow us to see and got an overview of many of the mathematical concepts involved with computational vision
Some knowledge of the biological processes of vision in primates and other relatively advanced animals, as well as how we can apply said concepts to building artificial vision systems.
More mathematical topics in computational vision - dimensionality reduction, curvature & differential geometry for example
The biological and mathematical concepts behind what it means to see
Understanding of computer vision and its relationship to human biology, with a high level of mathematics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is great, though linear algebra should absolutely be listed as a pre-req because of the amount of math involved in understanding the concepts

The content is very interesting, and the individual concepts in lectures are presented well. However, as the course progressed, the overall arc of the course seemed to flounder -- there were parts where the long-term implication or goal of the theory that we were developing was unclear.

* Unique, interesting, and very relevant approach to understanding computer vision
* Most of the homeworks were pretty interesting
* Quite unstructured  lectures were a little messy and final project was ambiguous
Does a good job of covering the mathematics and nuts and bolts of biological vision, but some parts of the course were  poorly explained and required follow up lectures

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom lectures were surprisingly good. The ability to rewatch the lecture recordings was fantastic to help understand the huge amount of material the course covered.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you have an interest in the topic and enjoyed 475 and have taken linear algebra, absolutely

If the topic seems like it might be interesting, and the student has good mathematical competency, then yes. Without solid understanding of a variety of math, it is somewhat more difficult to get a good experience from the course, but this should of course be expected.
Yes if you're interested in learning about computer vision from a more theoretical angle!

Yes, if you have a strong math background. The course pulls on many concepts from mathematics, physics, signal processing, and others, so having a strong math and engineering background is almost a requirement.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
